body:
- https://eslint.org/docs/rules/comma-dangle, enable "functions"?
 - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/padded-blocks, make always/never include switch statements?
 - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/object-curly-newline change the default from "multiline" to "consistent"?
 - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-len enable all the ignore options by default?

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/comma-dangle, enable "functions"?

I think we shouldn't enable it.
Because our default `ecmaVersion` is still 5, `comma-dangle` rule's default behavior shouldn't make syntax errors in ES5.

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/padded-blocks, make always/never include switch statements?

Looks to include switch statements already. ([demo](https://eslint.org/demo/#))

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/object-curly-newline change the default from "multiline" to "consistent"?

Sounds good to me.

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-len enable all the ignore options by default?

`ignoreRegExpLiterals: true` looks reasonable since Regular expression literals disallow line breaks. I'm not sure about other `ignore***` options.

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-self-assign "props": true?
> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-undef "typeof": true? (refs #10203 )

Sounds good to me.

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/object-curly-newline change the default from "multiline" to "consistent"?

:+1:

> > - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-len enable all the ignore options by default?
>
> `ignoreRegExpLiterals: true` looks reasonable since Regular expression literals disallow line breaks. I'm not sure about other `ignore***` options.

I think the default behavior of `max-len` should be to enforce a maximum line length, without any caveats. Changing this seems like it would violate the [principle of least astonishment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment). (It's not always the case that users want to ignore RegExp literals -- for some projects the solution to a long regex would either be "simplify it to make it shorter" or "use the `RegExp` constructor on concatenated string literals.)

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-self-assign "props": true?

:+1:

> - https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-undef "typeof": true? (refs #10203 )

I'm not sure about this. It's pretty common for code to do something like:

```js
if (typeof possiblyExistingGlobal !== 'undefined') {
  doSomethingWith(possiblyExistingGlobal);
}
```

In this case it doesn't make sense to specify `possiblyExistingGlobal` as a global in configuration, because the user would still want to disallow it outside of blocks that are guarded with a check for its existence. It seems like it would be annoying to add an `eslint-disable` comment for every `if` statement like this.* Given that most ESLint users use `no-undef`, I'm leaning towards not wanting to change this default because it would cause a lot of ecosystem churn from false positives.

*Currently, it's necessary to use an `eslint-disable` comment anyway for every use of `possiblyExistingGlobal` inside the block. I think we should fix this (there have been a few proposals about it in the past), but it's a separate issue.

> use the RegExp constructor on concatenated string literals.

that would be both astonishing and a bad practice.

As evidence that this is actually a thing that people do, here are some examples from the `nodejs/node` codebase, which used to use `max-len` without `ignoreRegExpLiterals` (although the config was changed later):

[1](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/65d97c96aa59517f90c34bf5a6b962e1b5e42316/test/parallel/test-buffer-alloc.js#L947-L948), [2](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/65d97c96aa59517f90c34bf5a6b962e1b5e42316/test/parallel/test-buffer-writeint.js#L10-L11), [3](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/65d97c96aa59517f90c34bf5a6b962e1b5e42316/test/pummel/test-crypto-dh.js#L42-L43), [4](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/65d97c96aa59517f90c34bf5a6b962e1b5e42316/test/pummel/test-crypto-dh.js#L51-L52)

Opinions clearly vary about whether this style is appealing. Still, I think configuring something like `max-len: [error, 80]`, the user is telling ESLint that they would like their line length to be capped at 80. Maybe this isn't actually what the user wants, but I don't think ESLint should silently override what the user said and enforce something different. If it turns out that the user wanted to ignore regex literals, they'll find out soon enough when an error is reported, and they can change their config.

In my view, the user expectation in this case is different from the expectation when ESLint chooses defaults for most other rules, because the idea of enforcing a maximum line length is very simple. The user probably has a very clear idea of what they're trying to enforce when configuring `max-len`, in contrast to other rules where the user probably hasn't considered all the cases that the rule needs to deal with.

**TSC Summary**: This issue proposes changing the default behavior of some rules in ESLint v5.0. 

**TSC Question**: Which rule defaults should we change?

In [today's TSC meeting](https://github.com/eslint/tsc-meetings/blob/adef4bed53b4e3160c19e82e7736ee651f540ee0/notes/2018/2018-05-10.md#new-default-behavior-for-rules-in-50), the TSC decided to change the default for `object-curly-newline` to `"consistent"`, and to change the default for `no-self-assign` to `"props": true`.

issue.title: Breaking: new object-curly-newline/no-self-assign default (fixes #10215)

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This change enhances an existing feature of ESLint

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->

**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**

[x] Changes an existing rule (see https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/10215)

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

This updates the default for `object-curly-newline` to `{ consistent: true }`, and updates the default for `no-self-assign` to `{ props: true }`.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

Nothing in particular
